For a place like Morning Glory that prides itself on organic ingredients, fresh produce, etc, there is no excuse to be serving this kind of OJ.  It's pathetic, and anyone can easily  discern the difference.  If I wanted this kind of juice, I would've gone to a corporate breakfast diner chain like Denny's or Ihop.  Come on.  2.  No pancakes on the menu, which was aparently tinkered with.   I'm pretty certain I had eaten pancakes here before....with them being such a fundamental breakfast classic, I can't figure out the warped reasoning behind not having them on the menu now.  Forget the pancakes....it's not a choice I would have made, but fine.  The orange juice issue, however, tells me their standards are beginning to slip, so I'd be careful if I was the manager.  This is how any restaurant's downward spiral starts: with complacency and lax standards.  I hate giving them a lukewarm review, but other than that, still a solidly recommended place.

6nl4jX63jCOtjNvDuOa6ZQ.text: Lovely setting, average food, atrocious service. There are MUCH better places for breakfast in Phoenix.

PsK2FQsJhcRkHeS4aWwO3w.text: Went to Morning Glory Cafe at the Farm on Sunday, 10/9.  I almost always enjoy al fresco dining and especially LOVED the atmostphere here.  Liked that all food is grown on the property so I knew it would be fresh.  Had a tasty omelet that could've been bigger and WARMER when it hit our table.  Home fries were pretty cold.  Taste was good, temperature needs help by a warming light and/or wait staff to get it to table sooner.  Lots of pepper in food I ordered...I liked it, my friend wasn't thrilled w/ pepper taste.  You can't beat atmosphere at restaurant and surrounding farm area for a lovely stroll.  5 Stars for location and atmosphere, 3 stars for SIZE of omelet and cool temperature of food (so, overall will give it 4*)

HzYDRJfrak2sFz3ng-2X6w.text: This used to be one of my favorite places to eat. But that was when I weighed 200 lbs. Now I follow a very low carb diet, and there is not much on the menu for me. The omelette automatically comes with potatoes and a biscuit. They have NO low carb options to substitute for carbs, and the waitress acted like I had asked her for a bar of gold when I asked if they could do sliced tomatoes instead of potatoes. They could not, by the way, because tomatoes aren't in season. Despite the fact that I had told her I cannot have carbs, she offered fruit, which--duh--is carbohydrate too. I expect people who serve food for living to actually know that! They also didn't offer to charge me less for my meal and leave off the carbs, nor did they suggest any other substitutions. Bottom line, if you have special dietary needs, don't bother with this restaurant. It's the only one in the valley that has NOT been helpful in accommodating my diet, and no omelette is worth $10.95 without at least a side of something. The price of the coffee was outrageous as well, $2.75 for plain jane coffee, and not a packet of Splenda on the premises. They also ran out of coffee. Give me Starbuck's any day, for that price! As for atmosphere, we were seated under a tree that kept dropping crap on our table, hair, and food. The waitress forgot to bring the OJ my companion ordered--all the other drinks were self serve buffet style, meaning you got to stand around in a line and wait to serve yourself. Morning Glory is definitely no place I will go again.

b7V8cz8Z67ljZv4N7xNcgg.text: Really liked this place food was excellent and the restaurant sits on the back of this beautiful farm.  Our family had a really good time and we will be going back soon.

AEN-kmCnkfGf3SzXAaVGVw.text: Flew into Phoenix at the buttcrack of dawn and needed some breakfast to get  out of a zombie state. The Farm at South Mountain was just the thing. The farm is so quaint and peaceful and wonderful to walk around. Breakfast at the Morning Glory was perfect. I had the breakfast special enchiladas, which where flavorful and filling. My partner had the brioche french toast and was so content (and he considers himself a french toast connoisseur). Sitting outside under the trees was awesome, there was a rooster waling around crowing his little head off, and the service was attentive and friendly. Coffee was good too! Definitely the spot to go for a breakfast or brunch!

CyNzUy5H6VmpZc0m3pjeGw.text: Everything was great here... Service, food, atmosphere, surroundings. Highly highly recommend, visitor or if you are a local. Make sure to go around the grounds and the shops.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Their yummy Signature Dish, Monte Cristo. Syrup on the side a suggestion. The grounds are beautiful around while eating.

85hUXRkrkSRqL2UYhiTLAQ.text: Delicious and worth the wait! We had a farm omelette, Monte Cristo and farm breakfast burrito. All were so yummy! The biscuits were mouth watering too. To add to all of the yum is the surrounding farm where they get their vegetables. There is so much charm to explore while waiting for a table. You have to try it!

kj2AUwHtEpwzwVo9gejn_Q.text: Stop and smell the SUNSHINE and a hearty Brunch!  This is such a wonderful outing and the service is stellar.  We will be back!

1LDp0H4GM-b6ZpASazPRKw.text: Great atmosphere and excellent customer service but my meal was completely underwhelming. I ordered "the American breakfast" eggs, biscuit, sausage and home style potatoes. Scrambled eggs are what they are hard to make them bad so that was fine but my biscuit didn't taste as fresh as expected, the sausage was dry and over cooked and the potatoes had no flavor at all. Cute place but at $12 a plate I had higher expectations of the food.

sFXhs2MWpQnNbxLAlMc6Aw.text: A must visit everytime I am in Phoenix.  I wish I knew this was here when I lived in Phoenix.  The scenery is just  gorgeous! It is always busy but the scenery and set up you never feel rushed nor does it feel crowded.  The whole premise of The Farm and Morning Glory Cafe is sustainability and quality, which they definitely achieve.  Everything I have eaten is delicious and fresh.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Beautiful place
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Mimosas with fresh squeezed orange juice
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chilaquiles with Smoke Pork ... Red and green sauce. Delicious!!!

3Il2pM2YJ0t-onsuZOeZ8Q.text: This certainly isn't a spot I'd go every week but for a special occassion (family visiting, etc) it's a great spot to grab breakfast or brunch.  The farm is a lovely setting.  If you haven't been there before there are a few restaurants on the property.  This one is in the far back.  I found the food to be very good (better than the other casual eatery at the front).  The ingredients are super fresh (you can see the veggies being grown next to the restaurant) and the portions were sized appropriately.    The cost is on the high side for a breakfast but again, you're paying for atmosphere as well.  Give it a go but expect a long wait on weekends.

rN9bo-I4HhVtKQYnKPQy0Q.text: I went to breakfast with some friends at the Morning Glory  (The Farm) after a hike on South Mountain last Sunday. It's been awhile since I had been there and noticed the new picnic tables and how they all matched, loved it!!! We were quickly greeted by Barbara who did a fantastic job from start to finish!! No chasing her down. She was on it! The coffee and food were great as I remembered. A place to add to your must go list.

UHnlj2GGAr1c_feAEYItvQ.text: The best word to describe this place is 'Charming'.  I love sitting on the patio, enjoying breakfast while enjoying the atmosphere of the trees and the singing birds.  The breakfast is fantastic.  Today I had the chicken enchiladas with 2 over easy eggs on top and green chile verde.  I think the tortillas are homemade.  So good.   If you like chicken fried steak, they have it as a special every now and then, and it is the best I have ever had.  They close for the summer, but we will be back in the fall.  Only negative thing is that they have SO many good dishes, it's often difficult to decide what you want, especially when you're hungry!!

i993pwburF41ttDZWNHWzQ.text: Probably our favorite place to eat breakfast.  The scenery is what you come for and the food is pretty good also.  It can get busy, but every time I have been sat fast.  I don't know how I feel about the serve yourself drink station, but the environment makes up for it.  The weekdays are not as busy as the weekends. Therefore, during the week they do not have some of the entrees served on the weekends.   Visit their produce stand if it is open, because I love the idea of supporting our local farmers.

k3_p3pH4J5aJzsl_Fn88Sg.text: The food and ambiance was nice especially on a perfect day in Phoenix. The Man and I waited 30 minutes for our table while drinking the self-serve lemonade which was more on the tart side. I ordered the waffle with a side of bacon and the man ordered the Monte Cristo. He slightly enjoyed his but should have subbed the ham for bacon. My waffle was nice but not as fulfilling as I'd like but I really enjoyed the fresh blueberries and strawberries atop.   This place really lost a star because there were soooo many flies!! They should think about putting in a fan or something because it was very annoying swatting away flies every 7 seconds. Would like to try the Farm for lunch one day though...

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Waffle with fresh berries

gbp_LjiZEmulXIrzYyEOfg.text: Very friendly family owned breakfast spot! Open Monday-Friday6:00a-3:00p. Limited menu & I got the Denver omelette which was yummy but they don't offer hash brown, home fries or potatoes of any kind.  They offered sliced tomatoes instead of toast for this gluten free girl! I will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. This is THE Mom &amp; Pop of Morning Star Cafe

mE_5wZJuyA_HU-6WTlMo9A.text: Great patio and it doesn't feel like you are in AZ. The self serve drinks and coffee was a little annoying but the food was very tasty. We shared the apricot scone and I had the special, chilaquiles with chorizo, beans, guac and sour cream. My guy had the trout omelette that was served with home fries and a biscuit. They first didn't offer jam so he  had to ask for it, doesn't seem like they are well staffed on a Sunday morning. This was my 1st time here and we went early ~9AM and I suggest you do the same as there was a wait as we left the restaurant. It's a   short walk as there is not right in front but it's cute to see the farm/greenhouse and little open businesses. Will go again as it is cooling down in AZ but I don't really see us coming in the summer, maybe for brunch after a hike at South Mountain.

XQ0pysXae_92-UbaeYyqeQ.text: Went here for breakfast and wasn't disappointed.  Service was good, plenty of tables and turnover seemed manageable for the staff.    Food was fresh and was as expected.  Had an omelet and the French toast.  Would recommend either as a good choice for your breakfast.    Only drawback to this place is that you are definitely paying a higher price (especially for breakfast) because of the "atmosphere" and venue you are in.  However, I didn't mind paying that upcharge.  From what I saw there seemed to be a lack of restaurants in the area, especially for breakfast.    Would come here again, and wouldn't think twice about giving it as a recommendation.

Za1_uEydfRz3rpK8ZR6y7A.text: Loved breakfast here this morning. A little hard to find, but worth the effort. My husband had the special, and I had the farm burrito. Everything tasted incredibly fresh and homemade. Good coffee and delicious freshly squeezed oj. I loved the beautiful scenery too. We would absolutely come here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Breakfast!

BwRcBvuEDgsKGq2VI-M1jw.text: This place was AMAZING! I didn't really read a description on this place before going, but I looked on Yelp and saw it had 4 stars and the pictures showed bomb looking food and a cute patio so I went for it.   Because I hadn't read any reviews, I did not realize the restaurant was on The Farm. I had trouble funding the place because there were only signs for The Farm and none for Morning Glory Cafe. Once I stepped on The Farm though I was blown away! Who knew a place so green and country could be found in Phoenix? There were rows of planted veggies and beautiful trees. We turned a corner and saw the quaint little patio nestled under some shady trees.  The hostesses were very nice. It was a long wait. But there was a cute little shop and some local vendors where I bought a few little souvies while we waited. We walked the grounds and had such a relaxing little Sunday.   The food itself was amazing. It took about 45 minutes to come out, and after the 1.5 hour wait for the table we were starving. I got the Back to Your Roots, which was a plate of fresh veggies and potatoes grown right on The Farm! It was incredible! The best meal I've had in months.   In short, plan to spend you're whole morning there unless you get there early. But the food is worth the wait and The Farm is a super cute place to explore.

AOrKwPJkrgTeWzvlm6CdYg.text: I have only been here with a large group. Each time (3), I thought the service was excellent and the food very tasty. I love the ambiance and am so glad we have this little jewel in the Valley.  From the Monte Cristo to the homemade granola and omelets, the food is solid and I think the portions appropriate.   My only complaint about Morning Glory is the self serve drinks. The price should be posted. I am not cheap but would like to know the ice tea will be included for $2.75. After paying my bill, I made sure to stop by and get a refill.

C5FADnDFh2OQa3RlX3_kGw.text: While searching for a breakfast spot, that was not to full and near the airport we came across this little gem.  The food is simple and good. I got eggs with cheese and I was happy that my food wasn't soggy with oil or over done. The buttermilk biscut was a treat!   The mimosa was a surprise and a bit overpriced. They give you OJ in a glass and a small glass bottle of champ to mix your own. The upside is that one my second one (yeah I roll like that) I just added the extra bottle of champ to my leftover mimosa and the OJ was a little treat for BCBP.   The service is laid back. You get your own coffee and the server will do most of the rest. The guy waiting on us was cool and overall I was happy.  The location is fun. There are chicken you can go and see and it feels like you are tucked away in another place. It doesn't feel like AZ because of all the green.  Just an FYI if you suffer from allergies, when I was there the pollen was raining down. Take your allergy pill beforehand!

9LBvbwx99k-rnxc8bp4yRg.text: I do love the atmosphere out here - very fresh in the glorious outdoors. But the flies.... ew. The food is well-prepared and the selection is marvelous. Love the homemade granola, the flavorful omelets, and the coffee is terrific. Good service too. But remember you're outdoors and there are bugs.

qWtH5Dljyp563CNpnvdNtA.text: The Brioche French toast is to die for! I loved the farm-to-table experience so much I had to come back and bring the whole family! I love that Morning Glory Cafe is located at the back of the property because it gives opportunity to explore the whole property before you leave!

2RZNq3-2mromI3D-BSAKhQ.text: I have been here multiple times for breakfast and always enjoy it!  Food is good. Menu has nice variety. Service is always good. Atmosphere is good.  Seating is all outdoors.  Plenty of heaters if needed.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States

yqTYqPZPgdgqL1kLBImxjQ.text: Holy cow, we brought some friends (who are visiting from put of town) for break fast on the morning of valentines, so delicious. The outdoor seating is beautiful on the farm with produce gardens visible from the tables. They had brought propane heaters as it was cool and cloudy. A truly unique dining experience with delicious food. We look forward to going back for lunch and dinner for sure! Fyi, many of the drinks are self serve.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States

j1c_UreLZWAPhrz44HnqeA.text: This place is a hidden gem. The food was extremely fresh and it's at the farm. Food fresh from the farm to the table. We had breakfast and were so overwhelmed with the great food we returned the next day.   I had the monte Christo and the next day the pork omelette.

AvjvjsVQYAvQ_XVyArcA7g.text: Service, food, ambiance. Excellent experience!  The service: staff were attentive with a smile. The food: hardy-sized scrumptious meals with a nice variety of plate options to satisfy all palettes!   Finally, ambiance: the grounds allow for a pleasant stroll previewing permaculture concepts and other beautiful, peaceful settings.   Enjoy!

7K1YgDksLR4Bkho0x2v7qg.text: We came here a Sunday morning around 9am. We did not have to wait but it was already pretty busy. The ambiance of this place is great. It is very peaceful to eat breakfast under huge trees. It was windy that day which made it a little difficult to keep cups on our table and tree leaves out of our food and drinks. I had coffee which is serve yourself and the chicken enchiladas. These were pretty good. The breakfast is comparable in price to other brunch places. After the meal we walked around and saw the crops being grown and the chickens and turtle. We also did a little shopping at the artsy vendors that they had our front. I would definitely come here again just for the ambiance.

m5EWL2eerpu6x6le6gml2Q.text: The food is worth the wait!! There are not many places were I am willing to wait to be seated to eat. But I will wait an hour or more at Morning Glory Cafe.  Plus they have a lot for you to look at, buy, and see as you wait, so that helps. This gorgeous property not only has amazing breakfast, but they cater to many weddings and events. They have fresh produce and homemade goods to buy in their little shop. On some day's they have a little farmers market to come get their freshly picked produce that comes right off of their farms.   But back to the food... I got the special that day. It was their CHILAQUILES: Crisp tortilla with housemade roasted red and tomatillo salsas, two fried eggs, melted cheddar and Monterey Jack, pico de gallo and a drizzle of crema. Topped with shredded pork. The pork was a little sweet yet had a little spice, and was nice and tender. But my favorite part was the housemade roasted red and tomatillo salsas. I need an entire bucket of that so that I can put it on it on EVERYTHING, or drink it... whatever. It was so perfect. Sweet and tangy. Mmmm...   I highly suggest putting this special on your regular menu. If not I hope you they take requests.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. French Toast
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. The Special of the day. Their Chiliaquiles Topped with Shredded Pork.

6DsvePR10cYQOjMyarUOjw.text: What a nice hidden place to have breakfast! Services was top notch! Breakfast was delicious and so was desert.  They were also not shady with their mamosa drinks ;) Pet friendly! And plenty of space to walk off. Will definitely be coming here again and again and again.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States

ZbW13iP7XGMgXjhYip1BIQ.text: The morning we visited was a bright and sunny one. It was a perfect day for an outside breakfast. We were their first guests at five til the hour.     Taylor was our high energy server and she seemed so excited that her words came fast.     The Back to the Roots dish was an amazing medley of yummy veggies with scrambled eggs on top. There were carrots, onions, yellow squash, zucchini, bell peppers, mushrooms, broccoli, and cauliflower. This came with O'Brien potatoes and a biscuit.      The All American came with scrambled eggs, thick bacon, and potatoes with a biscuit. I added some serious sausage gravy to make my biscuit perfect.    The ambiance here is unique and enjoyable. To reach this place, turn into a dirt road with a sign for the Farm then drive back as far as you can. There's parking on the left.    It's said that the restaurant will be slammed by 9:30 AM and I can see why.  This is not an inexpensive place but it is the place for good food and a neat environment.

PyEVgCkYgAvNnNX2iHFYjg.text: This is an outstanding breakfast spot that I cannot wait to go back to! They have a large, dog friendly patio and plenty of seating. The service was quick and friendly and food was outstanding! I highly recommend the farm burrito.   There was about a 25 minute wait, but we anticipated that since it was about 11am on Saturday morning. The grounds of The Farm are beautiful and give you plenty of scenic areas to walk around and kill time while waiting. They also had live music and mimosas for purchase while you wait.

97qrlL3M-_ht7x7aDqqi2A.text: Great spot, perfect place to bring anyone! My only gripe is it is ALWAYS busy. Plan on waiting at least 15-30 minutes for a table, ESPECIALLY on the weekends.

FS7PA6xLflcWHZhwlK6V5w.text: Loved this place!  We found it as we were looking for a breakfast spot before catching our flight back to NYC.  What a pleasant surprise as we said farewell to Arizona!  The food was outstanding, but a tad on the spicy side.  I didn't care for the chirizo, but the rest was fantastic.  It is outside seating only, so although it was a chilly morning, they had many heating units to keep us warm.   You definitely don't want to go if its terribly cold or rainy.  But the staff was friendly and helpful!  And we loved our visit to the gift shop.  Thanks Morning Glory for the great breakfast.  We'll be back again on our next trip!

NfAsbFGh3CKlCm3oP-5ysg.text: You can't beat the ambiance. Nice patio views of the Farm. The food was great, even my husband couldn't find fault. I will be adding the Morning Glory Cafe to my list of favorite brunch places in Phoenix.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States

owO81YLzzUf4EXeXgH3HZA.text: What a gem!!! So beautiful!!! Ignore the neighborhood this place was so worth the trip. They have done a fabulous job with the property and the staff. Our food was . Definitely kid friendly also.

RRR0yPUrAwkZp-cpHxdtmg.text: Disclaimer: I am enamored with nature and the farm-to-table concept. I think it's a brilliant shift in our society that is so disconnected with where our food comes from. That being said, I've been to the farm for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Thus far, breakfast blows the others out of the park...err...farm.   My breakfast absolutely blew me away. I had the Farm Burrito with scrambled eggs, refried Arizona tepary beans,potatoes, cheddar cheese and pico de gallo wrapped in a locally made flour tortilla. They serve it with sour cream, salsa, and home fries.   My mouth is watering right now remembering this. It's one of the best breakfasts I've ever had. I didn't bother talking to my breakfast date. I was more interested in the burrito.   It was a dog friendly patio which created for a great ambiance outside on a beautiful Sunday morning. Complete with a mimosa and a Bloody Mary, the day couldn't have been much better.

lTq_o5OmR34mf-LwSCg7Ng.text: Fantastic location,  delicious food,  great bloody Mary's.    Some of the items were local farm dishes that they prepared from the food grown on property and the beans were fantastic the local sauces was the wishes fresh but the only downside Was the Turkey sausage was not so good.

LmgROlJmfi-rFy9vavuaNw.text: I had a great experience here. The whole property is awesome to check out. It being a farm and all you can imagine that the food was delicious. Even tho it's hard to mess up breakfast food, still some of the best french toast I have ever had. And the Monte Cristo is a must try. Water coffee etc is self serve so as long as youre okay with that this place should be on the list.

MidvZbk73qIsicQZnzNjMw.text: Ughhhhh, what an awful experience. The Farm is beautiful though so five stars for that. The wait was 1 hour and forty minutes. We only waited because we had a cold, Land Lubber visiting from snow country. We sat at the picnic tables soaking op the 97 degree day. Or at least she did. We were hot.   Then, after waiting all that time we were told to get our own drinks.The drinks were self serve, huh? We then waited 40-50 more minutes for our food to be delivered. There were all types of issues with the food. In fact, what they did was a bit unethical in our mind switching ingredients in the special and not telling us or the servers until it hit the table. They did not inform the other wait staff either. We watched other servers taking orders for a dish that they supposedly ran out of it. But the catch was, they did not really run out of it. It was all very confusing and strange. The chef and managers here need to work on their communication skills.   I ordered the Best sandwich and it was not aptly named.  My food was cold. The only reason I did not send it back was because after waiting almost 3 hours I was starving. It was not good at all. It lacked any type of flavor and again it was cold.   We had a lot of other dishes on the table to try.  The biscuits and gravy were also cold. They did bring us a new one on that one. I must say, they are actually pretty good here. After complaining, my two friends finally got their dish after they said they ran out. Still am confused on that. Did they really run out? If so, how did they make it? They did say it was very good.   I gave two stars instead of one because the other dishes were said to be good and the place has really nice ambience. The servers are also nice. It was not their fault. They tried to make up for it and seemed sorry. I think we would have preferred a comp though. ( And I never ask for that.)  All in all, I would never wait almost two hours to eat breakfast ever again and the food is expensive for what we got. I have been wanting to try Quinessence for awhile. I might give that one a try some day but pass on the Morning "unglorious" experience.

JHWNn6h-LZBDt8i10ItBAQ.text: Let me start by saying that I love this place! The setting is beautiful, peaceful and very unique. It is part of what was once a very large multi acre farm that the Heard family purchased back in the day to study the Arizona canal systems.  It is still a working farm today providing fresh produce, eggs, crafts and best of all........restaurant services.  The breakfast here at the Morning Glory is always very fresh. The herbs and vegetables are grown here,  the coffee is robust yet smooth and iced tea is always refreshing. I have yet to try the morning libations offered but they are on my list. Lol I typically get the smoked trout omelette with egg whites, potatoes and fresh homemade biscuit. (I hand the biscuit over to my bf since it's not gluten free :(( ). The biscuit comes with a side of fresh homemade strawberry preserves which is DELISH!  After a wonderful relaxing scenic breakfast, it's a joy and pleasure to walk around the farm exploring all that is offered.  They provide three restaurants in one location. (breakfast, lunch and dinner) There are also three areas for events including weddings, showers, birthdays and special celebrations.  The staff is very friendly and a accommodating and facilities clean and satisfactory.  Come and check this place out! You won't be disappointed.

mdmwsn4ADVxDVLKxpDmH4g.text: Great Place to have a Breakfast in the morning. We sitting outside under the Trees. Delicious America Breakfasts.

e6frc0-mP3qM10-Bc59SQQ.text: ...recently my interview travels would take me to Phoenix/Scottsdale, a place I'd never really considered before, but a place with a job that just seemed "right" and a number of fellow gourmands, foodies, and chow-hounds who really reached out with their recommendations and offers to meet up for meals - a great group, each and every one.  With days jammed packed this short trip would actually prove to be a little tricky in planning but after getting a general feel for the local logistics the restaurants fell into place nicely with breakfast, lunch, and dinner planned strategically each day along with a few snacks.  Beginning first with breakfast, just as my trip did, there were three proper sit down breakfasts in The Valley and the first took place less than an hour after I hopped of the plane at The Farm at South Mountain.  With bags packed light and my car easily obtained the drive to Morning Glory Cafe would be a straight forward 15 minutes from Sky Harbor Airport and arriving at the large farm I proceeded down the gravel path through gardens of streaming sunlight that I quite simply did not expect to see in the "desert."  With signs delineating the location of the cafe (and the oft raved Quiescence next door) parking was found under a shady tree and checking the thermostat, 87 degrees Fahrenheit at 8:45am) I hopped out of the car and walked down the path to the restaurant only to find the patio approximately 1/3 full.  Greeted promptly by a thin young woman and subsequently by the elderly gentleman who would be my server I was told to "sit anywhere you like."  Selecting a seat in the shade as my pale Midwestern complexion certainly was not ready for an hour in the Arizona sun it would be mere moments before Cliff would stop by with the menu and a bucket of condiments to inform me of the daily pastry special and to ask if I had any questions.  Requesting a coffee I was informed that the coffee, water, and tea are all "help yourself" and suggesting I'd need a minute to browse the menu I was told to take my time.    With the menu concise but full of excellent choices largely consisting of locally sourced meats and organic produce I spent a few moments weighing my decision and with my choices made I motioned to Cliff who stopped by to take my order and warn me "you'd better be hungry" before departing for the kitchen.  Undeterred by his warning I next proceeded to the coffee stand where biodegradable cups and lids were provided for both water and coffee and after getting a cup of each I returned to my seat where I sipped the thin and mildly acidic locally roasted Cafe Cortez coffee while awaiting my appetizer.  Prebaked but still warm, the first item to arrive at my table would be the pastry of the day - a Blueberry Muffin nearly the size of my fist and bespeckled with crystals of cane sugar.  First tasting the muffin as it was and then gilding the proverbial lily with salted California Dairies butter the muffin would prove to be quite impressive in its density but also in its fluffiness as the medium-size blueberries burst with flavor within the buttermilk batter with tinges of cinnamon tickling the palate.  With coffee refilled and a short wait as the patio filled another pair of tables with locals (and regulars judging by the greeting) Cliff would arrive perhaps twenty minutes after I was seated with the main course - the "Farm Monte Cristo" consisting of two thick slices of fluffy rustic French Toast sandwiched around slow baked local ham, two over easy eggs, and melting cheddar cheese.  Apparently expecting me to be overwhelmed by the size Cliff offered me a "good luck and bon appetite" before stepping away and with that I set out to douse the amalgam with warm organic maple syrup and take a bite; a bite that more or less redefined the Monte Cristo for all time as the bread was not the least bit oily but rather light and fluffy with a nearly croissant textured interior and slight yeasty notes mellowed by the syrup and the powdered sugar. Moving next to the ham-young, fresh, lean, and salty - and then the sharp cheddar and creamy eggs the flavor was in a word "perfect;" salty, sweet, creamy, crunchy, and at the same time surprisingly light.  It was not only the best breakfast item I had in Phoenix, but the best sandwich I've had in a very long time.  With Cliff returning surprised that I'd finished the meal and offering me a "good job" I joked (well, not really joked as I really did go for pastry and pizza afterward) that the sandwich "wasn't that big, but it was THAT good" and thanking him for the service I requested the tab while getting yet another coffee to enjoy while I checked my mail and another cup to go.  Noting now that the experience of such a great sandwich, setting, and service is not "cheap" ($23 with tax and tip) I can say without a doubt that if I do end up in Phoenix long term Cliff will not make the mistake of underestimating my capacity again because without a doubt I'll be a regular.

eVwqpuXx9UPSp3QuVQcf-w.text: I had known about the Farm, but in all my years living in the valley (I'm a Phoenix native, so there's a lot of years there ;), I had yet to go.  We had a "Mommy Day" planned (two out of the three are/were pregnant and the day consisted of breakfast, mani/pedis, and finished up with a baby shower.) which started out at MGC.    The second pregnant pal suggested we go to MGC for breakfast and everyone readily agreed.  When we arrived, our orders were taken swiftly.  I must say that they are very accommodating at MGC.  I had asked if I could order hard boiled eggs instead of scrambled/fried for my breakfast and they were more than happy to oblige my breakfast revision.    My only quibble is the fact that we were not aware that you had to pay for the self-serve beverages.  After trying/disliking the lemonade, I went back for ice tea.  Thankfully, I was only charged for one.    Can not wait to go back once MGC opens back up this fall!

NdLvUSajV2TNQLPG-n2M4A.text: It took a while for the food to come out, but I actually didn't mind because I got to enjoy and take in mother nature and the cute setting of the cafe (and that's a big deal coming from a typical fast paced/no patience for slow movers Jersey girl). Coffe and tea is also a serve yourself station so that kept me occupied while waiting for food and was a smart move on the owners' part (one less thing for the already busy servers). . Great cafe outdoors. Takes a while for the food to come out but it was packed.  The Cowboy Breakfast Chili & Eggs (AZ Power Ranches Beef, Local Tepary Beans, Melting Cheddar Cheese, Two Over Easy Eggs, Sour Cream, Fresh Cilantro, and Griddled Bread) was really good. I really liked my Spinach and shiitake mushroom omelet as well. The prices weren't too bad either with all things considered.

8IrzpgSaiEaXzYIZZQECMQ.text: My family has been going out to Phoenix for spring training for 30 years now, so we've seen a lot of what the city (and surrounding areas) has to offer, and I don't think I'm alone in saying that it gets a little monotonous. Super chains and greasy mom and pop shops permeate the market, and it gets to feeling like the fresh food revolution hasn't really hit the greater Phoenix area yet. But then you stumble across places like the Farm, and you get a little glimmer of hope that you can get a great meal here that doesn't leave you feeling about 20 pounds heavier-- it's possible people! It really is!  The setting itself is not what I've come to expect from Phoenix-- the Farm is lush with trees, has a bit of a funky Santa Fe vibe, and IT'S NOT ALL BROWN. At the end of the long driveway is Morning Glory Cafe, set amongst flower beds and underneath tall trees. It did seem to be all outdoor seating.   We were seated immediately and our attentive server took our drink orders (two mimosas, obviously), and we both ordered the eggs benedict on the recommendation of our waiter, who said the hollandaise sauce was particularly good that day. And it was! The dishes had just the right amount of it, and left you feeling full without leaving you ready to burst. Well cooked and well executed.   I definitely recommend this restaurant for a change of pace, and a breath of fresh air!

Sl3Lfznp5-cCtnZWMDPzxA.text: Fantastic Ambiance. So so service.  I don't like that you have to get your own water. Okay food.  I had some veggie/egg thing with truffle oil on top.  The best part was the turnips in it.

56WQWTxJDd2qWMxqI2Y-pA.text: After hitting up the downtown farmers market this past Saturday, the Hubs and I decided to give the Farm at South Mountain a try, since we are rarely in this area.  Although we were a bit confused on which restaurant was which, we ended up landing at the Morning Glory Cafe.  I must add, as other reviewers have noted, the scenery here is wonderful and unique.  That alone is a reason to stop by, but as food goes, I might just bring a picnic lunch or get lunch at the grill when I come back next time.  I found the food to be mediocre at best.  I had the breakfast tacos, which were served in a hard shell - I didn't know restaurants served those anymore, especially on a breakfast taco.  The taste was fresh, minus the shell, but nothing special that I couldn't make myself at home.  The potatoes on the side had good flavor, but I would have preferred them to be crispier... they were rather soft.  The Hubs had the french toast, which he seemed to love.  I really saw him enjoying the candied pecans on top.  I liked the self serve lemonade/tea/coffee, although non were anything to write home about.  So, if you're in the area and want to experience something different, I say why not try Morning Glory Cafe.  For me, next time I will try the deli/grill place at the front.  I love the idea of a picnic here on a beautiful spring or fall day.  Can't beat that!

NOiuUMimOID-UviQ-fVOew.text: My husband and I took his parents here for brunch on a Saturday morning.  All in all, it was a positive experience.  When we arrived we didn't feel like we were in Phoenix!  The pros: -The staff was really friendly and helpful -The food was delicious  -The patio is dog friendly -We didn't wait long for a table  The cons: -I am not sure how I feel about the self-serve beverages  -While most of the staff we met were friendly, our server seemed rushed and frustrated  Overall it was a good experience and I would go again.

_LZWeeZ0OoSK7uo_7bGIuw.text: Farm fresh food for decent prices? Yes please! Expect a long wait if you go on the weekends. Nothing fancy, just good, fresh food. Loved my Farm Omelet with seasonal veggies and goat cheese, biscuit was ok.

EncT8VG9_PAI1khIV9L9OQ.text: We stopped by Morning Glory cafe after a hike up south mountain.  I love going to the farm and the morning glory cafe is always enjoyed by our guests when visiting.  The cafe was packed and the service was a bit slow.  Please don't forget though the kitchen is quite small. I tried the chorizo omelet and it was lovely. The potatoes are always perfectly cooked and the biscuit is a nice complement to the meal.  Many healthy options to choose from and all fresh ingredients used!  Enjoy.

2yj_g3YMfPBVcKICE9iQ5w.text: Loved this place!  We were in Phoenix for Spring Training & it was my birthday, so after carefully reviewing yelp, I chose Morning Glory for breakfast. It was perfect!!!  The farm was darling, the cafe couldn't have been cuter, the service was great & the food was delicious.  I had the Farm Omelet, with a side of granola. The granola was so incredible, I had to buy some to go. My kids had the French Toast (yum) and waffles, which they devoured.y husband had bacon & eggs & said it was great.  We ate outdoors, and afterwards we went into the cute gift shop, toured the gardens and visited the farmer's market.  Possibly  the most perfect morning ever.  Thanks, Morning Glory!

YW-lvJ9d-zdwuHSNDeSEfw.text: We went here last weekend for the first time with friends.  Excellent food, and we had great service.  We liked this place so much that we went back for brunch today.  The chicken enchiladas are fantastic, as is the monte cristo.  Definitely my new favorite brunch spot!

m8Ps1B8NrYLGGYUkMSAR5w.text: Great experience! Loved the ambience (outside with nearby heater), the food (delicious breakfast!), and the whole unique experience of being on a farm and walking around afterwards. Would definitely go back.

a18Gj6goq_HquiFHCf4IJA.text: Excellent! I have been to Morning Glory Cafe several times and have never been disappointed. The restaurant is strictly for breakfast and has many options. I have had the monte cristo, eggs any style with fresh veggies, all american breakfast, and breakfast burrito. All are amazing and so fresh and light. They offer free coffee and lemonade, which is located on a table near the hostess. You walk up and get it yourself and refill as much as you want! The coffe is great and the lemonade is fresh! This place is so good, even when it was downpouring rain, my husband and I and the rest of the patrons stayed to finish their food. They did have umbrellas but in a monsoon like that, we still got relatively wet. So delicious!!!

oDRplu1uMONkyW7frg4wLw.text: My husband and I went here on a weekend in Phoenix that was actually pleasant and mild! The weather definitely helped improve my opinion of the place, as it is an outdoor restaurant. We had a slight wait on the Sunday morning that we went, which we didn't mind at all because of the lovely scenery at The Farm @ South Mountain. It definitely makes you forget that you are in the middle of the desert. We were seated at a 4-top, even though we were only a party of 2. It was nice to have the extra room! I got the American Breakfast, which included 2 scrambled eggs, home fries, applewood smoked bacon and a DELICIOUS biscuit that we had to order 2 more of, they were that good!  My husband had the local Schreiner's sausage, tomato and cheese omelette, which he really enjoyed, but I think he could have easily eaten a slightly larger portion. The food was really great! We had a really sweet server as well. The only complaint I have is that they had what looked like an all-you-can-drink beverage bar, where they were serving lemonade, tea and water from big canteens in plastic cups. Of course, we grabbed 2 drinks thinking "Oh, how nice!" Unfortunately, both drinks turned up on our tab. I would have appreciated someone warning us that they charge for the drink bar. But, that's OK. Now I am more informed and I would definitely come back here!

vhiNdoGNBJthF-vY4Uqdjw.text: Beautiful oasis in the midst of everything. Food was excellent and it was a calming spot on our way to the airport.

xD93xuwAgsXneRX3DKeqbA.text: They are open now!  Pleasant dining experience (minus the hot weather and flies).  Outdoor seating only and pet friendly.  Seasonal menu is fresh and food I had was really good!  Very fresh eggs.  One of the best breakfast I had in a while...  4 stars for food.  5 stars for being original, eco-friendly and supporting local growers.

MVHm0r_QHeIvEDxMmBWTUA.text: An absolutely perfect breakfast spot on a lovely day. For a Sunday between 1030 and noon, the wait was zero to ten minutes (pretty impressive for such a prime brunch hour). The grounds are gorgeous and shady, and include an entire farm and green house in which to walk off your meal, and the food was fantastic.   I had the All American Breakfast, which included a perfect sized serving of bacon, two eggs, a biscuit and hash browns. Everything was how you would want it to be - the bacon crisp, the biscuits soft and buttery, the eggs fresh and cooked to order.   My one complaint was the bloody mary, which was WAY too spicy. I'm not one to send a drink back, but it was ruining the meal because it was creating a reaction in my throat with each sip. I flagged down the waitress and asked to add more tomato juice to it to even it out (and she seemed to know what I was going to request before I said, leading me to believe this happens a lot and that they should reconsider their bloody mary mix recipe). But she was more than happy to correct it ... except that they had run out of tomato juice. I left the drink where she placed it back on the table, hoping I wouldn't have to ask to have it removed from the bill.   Smartly, when she came to drop off the check, she asked if we were done and if I wanted the drink. I said no, she then handed us the appropriate ticket. She had the smarts to print one with the drink on it and one without so she would be prepared for either answer, eliminating any awkwardness or time wasting by going back to re-print it. Seriously, it's that kind of simple act of foresight that makes me love a venue's service.  Oh, and they have wi-fi but I couldn't get my phone to pick up the network.

1tO2LhMWdpcUnLq-iGfDow.text: $35 for 2 atandard fare breakfasts out in the open with  leaves falling on your soon cold food and in your self served coffee in a paper cup. Not impressed.too many hundreds of better options everywhere.

NFK_-PI7BqPQesqMetJPAg.text: This is a cute spot! It is a bit out of the way next to South Mountain, but the rural farmy setting definitely benefits from that.   You enter by going up a long farm lane, passing between several buildings, an event lawn, a group doing yoga on the other lawn, etc. It is very picturesque and seems like a good place for a wedding or other party. There are several buildings at the end of the lane and Morning Glory Cafe occupies the patio of one of those buildings - you duck beneath a vine-covered arbor and enter the seating area. The tables are patio tables covered with plastic red gingham patterned tablecloths with menus scattered on them. You choose your own table and are advised to help yourself to coffee, iced tea, lemonade, water at the station next to the house. You can also order a few other beverages from your server - orange juice, mimosas, bloody marys, etc.   The menu is relatively brief but chock full of farm fresh ingredients. They have some interesting items - The Cowboy Breakfast Chili and Eggs, The Farm Monte Cristo, and the Chicken Enchiladas were all pretty unique breakfast fare and so we ordered one of each :) Browsing the menu, I learned that if you are a pancake/waffle/french toast/pastry lover, this is not the place for you. The food came out REALLY fast, which makes me think that they have most of the stuff ready to go in the kitchen and just garnish/sauce the dishes before sending them out. Itwas pretty good - I got the Chicken Enchiladas, which were filled with shredded chicken, covered with green chile sauce, and topped with Over Easy eggs. The temperature of the dish was less than great (a bit cold) and the yolks of my eggs were overdone, cooked all the way through. When I've had dishes like this before, the intention is that the yolks are runny and add moisture and flavor to the dish beneath. Since the eggs were overcooked, this didn't happen and it left the rest of the dish pretty dry (most of the green chile sauce was soaked into the enchiladas beneath) I did ask for extra chile sauce which was provided promptly, however it was very cold and did not spread well over the dish (I also could have still used even more of it, as the dish was SO dry)   We had a side of bacon that was delicious, and my husband enjoyed the Cowboy Breakfast Chili.   The setting was nice - we could hear roosters crowing and watch the activities of the farm/preparation for the day's events, etc. while we ate.  Service was decent - the girl who was our server was nice but a little brief - I was having trouble deciding and asked her for her favorite item on the menu. She said the Chicken Enchiladas but didn't really elaborate further, which didn't sell me on it. Her demeanor just came across as pretty uninterested.  I felt like the prices were quite high considering the type of place (outdoor picnic tables), service (serve yourself for the key stuff and overall a little less than friendly) and food (seemingly mass made, okay tasting, not quite right) We spent $60 for three people and I walked away just really feeling as though it wasn't worth $20 per person.  I did want to like Morning Glory Cafe, but in the end it was more of a "meh" meal.

qh1zEkqiYr4pFSYruC8O9w.text: Amazing place to go for breakfast!!! I've been here several times and the food is always amazing. The service is very quick and friendly. I highly recommend the Monte Cristo, it is definitely the best item on the menu. Just a heads up, there is parking right in front of the restaurant. It seems confusing because there are signs by the street directing you to a dirt lot across from the property.

41NYtIqRGOs-WI-OZtl70w.text: Great food for a good price. The staff is friendly patient. An outside atmosphere that is relaxing and enjoyable. The kids got up to play as the rest of us enjoyed the food. No complaint about the food, but the coffee choices could use some work. Regular or decaf. with refills..

Ujr13G5qJ8Jw7nN5ZvoCDQ.text: What a waste. Place looks like a cool spot for breakfast, but that was it. There were about 4 tables, and 2 waitresses, and they waited like 15+ minutes before even asking us if we wanted a menu. They did however stare at us several times, yet never making the jump to offer us anything. After we took a menu from the table next to us that finished, we finally got to order. Once the food came, it took another 5 minutes to get silverware. Non-fresh squeezed OJ(Big letdown!), and food was terrible. I had the breakfast burrito and my tortilla shell was stale. My sisters goat cheese omelet was rancid, and my other sisters scrambled eggs had a very weird taste to them(unedible). Only meal that didn't get too many complaints was the over easy eggs, except the yolk was cooked.   The weird thing was that the neighboring table's food looked so much better than ours. I don't understand, because we werent raudy or disrespectful or anything. We paid our bill, and left, and will never be back. Shame, because of the cool setting. Don't waste your money on overpriced breakfast!

4Idc35tVuAdQ1AK80Qbs5A.text: A good friend once said that everything tastes good with truffle oil.  I couldn't agree more, and that's just one of the reasons I love the Morning Glory Cafe.  Let's start with ambience.  It's an outdoor patio, with trees providing the shade.  It's morning on a farm, so the cock will crow every now and then.  Birds actually sing.  And it's Phoenix, so the weather is going to be perfect 99% of the time.  The coffee (serve yourself!) is a decent blend.  But the highlight of the breakfast was the veggie skillet - farm fresh vegetables done in a skillet (this mornings selection included fennel, squash and red onion), together with skillet potatoes, and topped with scrambled eggs finished with white truffle oil.  I know - it makes me salivate just thinking about it.  And that's what makes a good restaurant.

3g7femybcIEXZPHpaKbCTQ.text: I love every place on South Mountain. I've been wanting to try a Monte Cristo for awhile now. The wait was well worth it. Massive flavor explosion in the mouth. Finished it off, chased it with fresh lemonade, and seriously wanted to order round two. For sure will be back next week for that second one.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. the&#34; Farm Monte Cristo&#34; best thing ever!!!

bXnnARK2ecWCXcHRo2X4NQ.text: The atmosphere is amazing. The staff is friendly and the food is awesome. Favorite breakfast place

H609qmeTnYnHPRxRETC-IQ.text: I have loved Morning Glory cafe for YEARS. The grounds are beautiful and while I've eaten at all three of the restaurants at the Farm I love the Morning Glory Cafe most of all because I can sit in the grass nearby while I wait for a table to become available (yes, there will be a wait, especially on weekends) and I feel like I'm not in the dusty Arizona desert anymore.   I've also come to MGC for Mother's Day for two of the past three years and it's almost become a tradition for me and my daughter. However, this last Mother's Day really (really) disappointed me.   When I arrived we were told there was an hour wait. OK... No problem. I was expecting that (at least) and any other decent place would have a similar wait on Mother's Day. However, the issue was bigger than just the hour wait - the hostess who was calling people's names off the waiting list had such a faint voice that I couldn't hear her call my name - even though we were sitting right in front of her and I had gone up to ask her 10minutes prior if our table was ready. (You would think she would recognize me if I had just gone to talk to her and was sitting right in front of her but she seemed either clueless or overwhelmed).  As a result - we were passed up and FOUR other tables were seated before us. After figuring out we had been passed up I went back again and asked if our table was ready and the hostess didn't even apologize. I'm sorry but when you have over 50 people waiting at a time for their table, you can't put someone with the voice of a 9 year old in charge of calling names. I understand it's a farm and a loudspeaker would kill the ambiance but at least get a better system in place for making sure people get seated after they've waited so long for a table.   Finally we were seated, and drinks were self serve so we immediately got water/coffee. The wait staff was completely frazzled at this point in the morning. They were stopping at tables for no longer than 2min at a time and making beelines between tables and the kitchen so you couldn't even get their attention without causing a scene.   We ordered a good 15min after being seated even though we knew exactly what we wanted to order. An HOUR later we still didn't have our food and my 5 year old daughter (who normally has to be bribed to eat) started crying. I asked her what was the matter and she said "I'm so hungry!" Not exactly the kind of thing a mom wants to be dealing with on Mother's Day. It was so sad the table next to us started offering us food off of their plates to give to my daughter (how embarrassing).  The waitress walked by a few times and I said "Is our food almost ready? We've been waiting over an hour." Her response was "Yeah, so has everyone else" and walked away.   Finally I called our waitress back and I said "We ordered a cup of fruit. Can you at least bring that? My daughter needs to eat something." She came back with the fruit cup which my daughter inhaled and about 15min later we had our actual breakfasts (which were very good and well-made as always. Food never disappoints here).  I will say, that to "make up" for the wait, they gave us a complimentary dessert which was a nice gesture in the end but the whole experience has made me question whether I will go back for any special occasions.   Reason being - I've noticed the Farm grow in popularity over the years but there hasn't been any real improvements to their service. They still run the place as though they are getting the same amount of traffic as 5 years ago and that is obviously not the case anymore.   They could have done a better of job of getting us seated at the right time - or of getting a snack for my daughter if they knew the main breakfast was going to take longer than normal - or of telling us when we put our name on the list: "it's an hour wait for a table and another hour wait for food to be served" - so we could make a better decision as to whether we should stick around.   They need to find a way to keep it low key and quaint without putting people through the kind of experience we went through. Maybe a reservation system is needed for breakfast? Limit the number of guests? Idk, but they certainly shouldn't just leave people to wait over 2.5 hours to have their first meal of the day - especially when the majority of patrons in the mornings are families with young kids.   Again, isolated incident, but can't say that their seating system or wait staff are any more organized on other days of the year. Wait times for a table can be up to 30-45min on any weekend but normally food does NOT take over an hour to arrive.   Note: they have a separate Mother's Day brunch that you can purchase advance tickets for, and those have scheduled seating times. I have never taken that option because my daughter typically doesn't eat a lot and it would be a huge waste.

egD1uc_a1WYXmCZgL-Co3g.text: such an adorable spot if you're in the area and need a beautiful hangout to look at flowers, walk around the vegetable farm, and grab a bite to eat. There's an organic farm on the property and the tea and lemonade are self serve. The only main issue is that Arizona is hot and everything is outdoors. In addition there were lots of flies so everyone was swatting them with their menu. At the same time, people willing to overcome both of those issues must love the spot. Very cute. Would definitely recommend it to anyone near the airport!

HxUe1dFmBN-HH-nNEhXKew.text: Food was amazing! Staff was super friendly. I recommend it to anyone who is looking for a unique breakfast nook.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Huevos rancheros!
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Huevos rancheros!

MRblpYdI9un1Rrm_vyR2Gg.text: Excellent stop in a bit out of downtown, but worth the drive if you have kids.  Great food, lots of atmosphere....can you say animals and a working farm to distract the kids?   An absolute must if the weather is mild and you can get there early.  A bit later it gets too busy and limited number of tables can cause a wait.  Kids loved the self-serve beverages and we loved the flavor and local flair  Only reason it wasn't a five star was the amount of 'nature' that ended up in my coffee...lots of grass and seeds from the overhanging trees.  Guess I should have had a lid on my coffee  Dog friendly and very laid back vibe.  We will probably stop I on our way to airport, making it our only Phoenix repeat during our short stay

aXHGtT9TArsipixNFshn2w.text: What a cute little place to have breakfast!  I just recently attended a bridal shower brunch here and it was so cute!   The food was super tasty, I had the creamy corn porridge with maple glazed sausage and cinnamon sugar roasted apples. I took a chance on it, it sounded like it had a 50/50 chance of being either really good or really heinous! And boy was I glad when it came out and was soooo good!  This place could be 5 stars if the staff wasn't so lax and a little more attentive. This was the whole table (8 ladies) first time coming to this place, we were not instructed that drinks were self serves for the basics (water, coffee, juice) we had to figure that out on our own, and no one at our table was asked if they would like a mimosa or any other drink other then the self serve stuff.  I do look forward to going back!

tp8ScQjFqE4dtBylgJeQTA.text: I think this might be one of my new favorite spots for breakfast . The food was delicious, quality ingredients and large portions. I had the huevos  rancheros and shared the brioche French toast.  It's a nice get away from the city, within the city. The outdoor space was relaxing and service excellent. Looking forward to trying more from their menu!

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States

KUFeIommnmWJSOHepAIUDQ.text: I went here yesterday morning for brunch with my dad on my birthday and I thought it was really special. The farm is pretty, it feels like you are out of Phoenix for a minute. The food was excellent! We shared the cowboy eggs (or something like that) and the french toast. The cowboy dish was amazing, it is a big bowl of delicious, well seasoned, slightly spicy chili with two over easy eggs on top and two pieces of toasted and buttery bread. I thought it was a real gem. The french toast was also very very good. I am not super into sweet breakfast, but I might make an exception for this. The toast had a crispy outside and a soft inside, was covered in syrup and some kind of flavored butter, and topped with nuts...it was crazy good....I only deducted a star because it was my first time coming there and the place is a bit expensive, but there is no question I would come back here again. In fact....I want to go back right now!  Oh, Tip: I saw the parking lot across the street from the farm and parked there BUT it is a long walk from there to the restaurant and there is closer parking...just not a ton of it.

heHU9QMZbFU2o7jyTkCopw.text: Kind of pricey for what you get which is healthy, yes, but not very tasty. The pulled pork sandwich was too sweet and the coleslaw had no dressing or flavor (just shredded cabbage). $26 for two sandwiches and a bag of chips is a bit steep for a no service, no frills kind of place for lunch.

3mcf-YLejqPvpVn5wlQ0Ow.text: This is the way food is suppose to be.  Fresh from the farm.  Eggs taste like eggs and not bland, OJ is fresh squeezed, all their food is out of this world, and service is awesome.  Definitely a breath of fresh air.

fmQg8L7Q48fdvs6wFzSSXg.text: Got to say one of the best brunches I've had in AZ in my long search for such a place after moving from cali and being surrounded by gems like this one.  If you want quality fresh tasting food straight from the ground to the kitchen and then to your mouth this is the place. Brought my out of state mom for her bday she was in love, as a beach person she loves the outdoors and their outdoor dining did the trick for her. She even stated she would have never guessed she was still in Ph Phoenix. Between the 3 of us we ordered the monty crisco (my moms fav and so hard to find these days), the veggie skillet, and an omelette. None of us wanted to share! For the slightly urban hippie I feel I am meant to be I'm in heaven here. I will be back again and again and promise to try the bloody mary.

fUasLyiv1T-UjqQyRtYLCQ.text: I have farm envy. This is the most perfect location I've found to date. Upon driving down the lane you see one quaint restaurant with a bunch of picnic tables, an event and wedding party area and a photography studio. Continuing down the dirt lane there are plots for different fresh produce, cacti, and ultimately two more restaurants.       Morning Glory is so cute. Self serve drinks, all outdoor seating and a casual, fresh-aired, relaxing environment. We got seated immediately before the church rush, grabbed hot coffee and soaked up the morning sun. I ordered their farm omelette after battling and eyeing up the brioche French toast. The omelette had broccoli, cauliflower, carrots, spinach and cheese covered with fresh tomato salsa. The salsa had a nice spicy after taste and the omelette was so thick and well made. Their biscuits are flaky, buttery and delicious with a slice of grapefruit to add a little tang. This also Come with seasoned breakfast potatoes. My brunch date got the "pork is the new black" omelette and was on food cloud nine with the sausage gravy over the top.   Everyone should check this little spot out. Have a picnic. Drink a mimosa. Buy a cacti. Support local!

0_8pOi1Ake8rqGvGqaaS1g.text: Nice to go to see something different and get a different experience. i really liked the atmosphere of the farm. cute, picnic tables, a few chickens, lots of fruit trees, very pretty and calming to walk around the farm.   but, in rating the restaurant, i would give it 0-1 :( food was not tasty at all. was expecting so much more from this place! went there for breakfast. 1st thing, they didn't have fresh squeezed OJ. how can a farm not having fresh squeezed OJ?? i think it was around $3 for a small glass of OJ that he took out of the refrigerator gallon bottle and poured it in. very expensive, overpriced for the food that sadly wasn't something i would go back for. i had gotten some sort of a scrambler and my husband got the french toast. the scrambler was ok and the french toast was drowning in syrup, wayy too sweet and heavy.   also, we waited about 45min on a saturday morning to get seated, which was expected, so no big deal about that.  but, i was expecting much better tasting food for a place that's on a farm and so expensive. if i go back, i may just go to see the farm, but not to eat there again.   the weekend i went (in mid october), they were talking about how someone new had bought it and the ownership of the farm changed, so maybe they'll make or have already made improvements at the restaurant...?

AZ4n38Z6Em_q19uMHV2J5g.text: This place is pretty awesome. Really fresh food and a really great view. I would assume all food prepared comes from the farm that you are eating at. Sure taste like it! Its great that they do pick up orders as well, i work down the street and when i have to be at the office on saturday/sunday mornings this is my go to place

RhgtZI-Uuy5s3AZ9bkXxQw.text: They just opened a couple of weeks ago now for their season while relies on good outdoor weather. Although it was very warm by the time my friends and I finished our breakfast, which we began at 9:30am, it was a great eating experience. Granola with fruit, French toast, corn porridge and my omelet were all enjoyed! Looking forward to going back another time when it gets cooler weather there in the Phoenix countryside, or as close to that as we can get and still just be a few short miles from the city. It is a pet-friendly place. Tables set aside for people wanting to sit with their dog and enjoy their meal. Cool! We must have it hit lucky as we got the last open table when we arrived at 9:30. The man who runs the greenhouse is a fountain of knowledge and will explain exactly what to do with the plant you buy so that it lives a long life, so be sure to check that out, along with walking the property. Just enjoy the outdoors and you will swear you are not even in the Phoenix desert.!

3GdAVnPEpit4u2y1z4SXKA.text: Love this place for a variety of reasons and would go here for just about any occasion... Have spent Mother's day here @ Morning Glory (not separate buffet) for a few years and like to take friends here when in town or when we want a relaxed, filling, outdoors brunch. Great service and scenery! I would like to say all food is good but I can't pry myself away from the Monte Cristo French Toast to try anything else-- delish! Highly recommend.

dDQ6LsDnd5nOzpGy2PgbZg.text: This is my favorite breakfast spot in Arizona. The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming, and the food is always filling and tasty. From wandering through the gardens to observing chickens (and a turtle!), it's a place I have brought nearly every guest I've had visit from out of state- and not one has had a single complaint. I highly recommend!

bOwSnQNw_jPZISTFOxsjWQ.text: The location and ambience is outstanding, with the farm, animals and vegetation. That part is at home run.  The reason for 2 stars is that management didn't know where the Chicken comes from. Out of principle, I can't support a restaurant when there's a lack of knowledge for the source of the meat.  It was also my impression that one of the staff members and managers was laughing at the fact that I was asking this question.  Strictly speaking about the food, the huevos rancheros was uneventful and my omelette was dry and Seemed as if had been sitting for a while when It reached the table.  I'd happily be back if the restaurant could dial-in this one particular piece of their business.  As of all all of us vote with our dollars, I feel it's so important that we make decisions to support restaurants that have great practices in place.

3tRjJU_4WskxITibyZ46cQ.text: Super impressed by the area it made me forget I live in Arizona. The restaurant is seating outside only, but it wasn't as hot as you would think. There was breeze and I think it was because of the trees and grass. It really is a beautiful place to sit down and relax.  The food was SUPER delicious! I had the green enchiladas with egg and potatoes on the side. Every bite was better than the next! My friend had the farm omelette with egg whites and I had a taste as well. The taste was fresh and the goat cheese gave it that extra yum flavor. I also had a mimosa that was good, but a little overpriced for the size and there was nothing special about it. They also have a self serve station for water, tea, and coffee which I thought was a cute unique touch to the restaurant.   Another plus was the customer service super friendly people. I will be back for sure to try one of their many other menu items.

Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Surrounding

TfuJTOmglzUJK_A85DPpMw.text: A little uninspired as far as the flavor goes. It seems the chef took fresh ingredients to mean no spices or innovation. I got three bites into the chilaquiles, and was bored from then on. Two bites for the biscuits and gravy. Way too pricey. I might give this place another star if the prices were lower, but I don't pay these prices for that lack of flavor.  We waited more than an hour on a Saturday morning to be seated. It's on a gorgeous farm with plenty to see and do during the wait, just don't expect to walk up and sit down. Only outdoor seating available, so if you have allergies or an aversion to bird droppings plopping down next to you as you eat, be forewarned.

bzKpFFrTW65PgQIH1Dw61A.text: I'm very shocked at the service I experienced today.  We were a party of 10, everyone's food came together except for mine. We had already waited over 40 mins for our food to begin with, it was a large party so that was understandable. When I asked about my plate, it looked as though the waiter, Fausto R., had forgotten. Everyone in my party was almost done when my plate came, to my surprise my order was made incorrectly. I ordered the chilaquiles with over hard eggs but got scrambled.  The waiter said he would bring over hard eggs which took 12 minutes. Eggs do not take that long to cook. By the time i got the eggs the chilaquiles were soggy. I really thought he would at least apologize and give me some sort of reason but he didn't. When the bill came I really thought there would be some sort of apology and discount on my plate but there was not. So I requested that my plate be discounted off, he was not happy about that. My dad was eating my leftovers, so he said he couldn't take it off especially since we were still eating the plate, but would still bring it to his bosses attention and just walked away.  It took another 15 minutes for him to come back. The food was good and I love the setting but Fausto made the experience horrible. My brothers and I were there with my parents bc my moms father passed away and we were just trying to be together. It sucks that someone's attitude can ruin an experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States

K6KJprYcZrLAb9tAh3DThQ.text: This is such a great breakfast brunch cafe (on the grounds of The Farm at South Mountain) surrounded by all the beautiful plants and vegetables they grow. It is also one of the more beautiful outdoor patios on this side of town.     I work down the street and was craving one of their yummy egg burritos. Stopped in to order to go and out! I do recommend coming when you can sit and enjoy the outdoors. Everything on their menu is worth a try. Come early though! They close at 11am!

3vjpgpTXqqvvcooI76uGWw.text: Lovely setting..wonderful place for families and can be a great spot for a date ;-)  Delicious food!

UXDQQE0BgFhrboMxA6hygQ.text: A True 5/5 stars! Went to Morning Glory Cafe at The Farm at South Mountain for Mother's Day and was wonderfully delighted. Granted, there was a pretty long wait time but the weather was nice enough for us to walk around The Farm and take some pictures and see everything. From their gift shop with locally sourced items to their sustainable garden and greenhouse it was a treat to be able to see. Once we were sat to eat the servers were patient and kind despite the heavy traffic they had seen all day. There was an array of food to choose from that made it hard to pick, but our family of four all got different things and no one was disappointed! For those 21 and over they served seasonal mimosas as well. Overall, a wonderful brunch with a wonderful atmosphere. While my experience was 5/5, one thing to keep in mind is that it only has outdoor seating, making an iffy place for the summer. There was lots of shade but I am unsure how hot it would get in the AZ heat!

photos.caption: Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Morning Glory Cafe - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Outside seating

Jauj0sM7-z2SfQRMsmjDTw.text: I visited this place for brunch on my recent visit to Phoenix. The food was good. They have few vegetarian options and are also ready to substitute to accommodate vegetarians. I ordered the farm burrito without scrambled eggs. They substitute my scrambled eggs with vegetables. The wait time was not too much as we went towards the end of morning. This place is surrounded by the farm. You can walk in the farm and see the variety of plantation.

lQdXo6C6QYZ5XzzRxzZzfw.text: Well, it is eating outside...flies, birds, and all. It is also expensive for what you get. $3.50 per paper cup of self-serve coffee, and it is nowhere close to Starbucks quality coffee either. There is no choice how you're eggs are done; everyone gets over easy, whether you want them that way or not. Service is slow, and the food comes out slow as well. Bathrooms are a trailer with a 2-stall porta potty. There is nothing glamorous here...

7siP83RCacLOLpmOd-EDfA.text: I'm a first time visitor to Arizona and this place caught my eye because it is actually located on a farm! The food was spectacular and definitely fresh. I don't remember what exactly I ordered but I know it was full of wonderful seasonal veggies, eggs, and home fries. I ordered a side of bacon and avocado as well which complimented the dish perfectly! My only complaint is the pack of coffee choices. I think Morning Glory would really benefit by having more options like dairy free milk for coffee, lattes, etc. Other than that, it was spectacular!

o3HSkx4Jg5RDQkxr71tEBQ.text: Great food and great environment. There's lots to see. The food is amazing and they use locally grown food. I had the brunch chicken enchiladas. They were so good. Not spicy at all as they use tomatillo sauce. The mimosas were also good but could've used a little less orange juice.

Gk47Kht3Hv7tiwqagJFN1A.text: Tables are a little too close but overall a good place to sit out and enjoy the weather.

kR-SujEzAHqKB81P1YPpNQ.text: This is such a cute and cozy little breakfast spot. It is on a quiet farm with patio seating. The atmosphere was lovely. They have a self serve coffee, lemonade and water station which was super convenient.   We ordered the Chilaquiles and the American Breakfast. If you like breakfast nachos, you would absolutely love the Chilaquiles with chorizo. It's just enough spice too!   The American breakfast was perfect. Scrambled eggs, farm home fries with peppers and onions, bacon and a side of biscuits and gravy. The bacon and home fries were the star of the dish! I wish the gravy would have been a little thicker and for the biscuit to be softer but overall, it was pretty good.   The bloody Mary's were absolutely delicious! We just had to get seconds.   We are excited to come back and try more things from the menu!

hwSkHPGZqNc2aunhbTuIeA.text: Love this place, service and food are always A1.  Their mimosas are pretty good too.  They have daily specials that are always good too.

d4ZCQL6n5ipAKTfbYGaB_g.text: This place is a True diamond in the rough. It sets in the back of a farm and is simply a small hut with a kitchen and several picnic tables out front for the diners. From what I can tell its strictly outdoor seating and they serve breakfast only. There's a cafe towards the front of the property that does lunch. The food here was simply delicious. I had the breakfast burrito with smoked pork which was awesome. Others in my group had a smoked trout omelet and the French toast. Everybody at the table loved their meal and this cafe. This will be a regular destination for me in Phoenix.

tI_qbvLcQ8hynKJ1c-yKuw.text: We came here for my friends birthday, it's a great spot for a nice brunch on a spring morning. There were 6 of us, I personally ordered the Farm burrito, and added chorizo to it. It was flavorful and huge that I couldn't get a handle on and had to eat with a fork and knife. Service was ok, very little interaction with the staff as they take your order and they're gone until food is out. We got our own drinks and coffee which at times we had to wait in line. One thing I noticed that there is a discrepancy on their menus between the online menu and their menu offered there as prices for some of the items differ thefarmatsouthmountain.c... Also, keep up with the 21st century morning glory folks, the fact that you do not split checks is one reason that I may not come back with a group of friends however I Will come back another time if it's family and one check is presented.

4_utB1jbgrFVNtncXYRc1w.text: 03/18/2018 First time here!! Beautiful outdoor farm along with chickens. The wait time on a Sunday around 10am was 25 minutes. There is plenty to see and enjoy while you wait. The service was really quick and friendly. I definitely enjoyed the outdoor eating this time of year. Plate range from $12 & up for very good quality ingredients.

v3hcsFlcBLHqsykGXHWyYA.text: This place is amazing! The scenery alone is enough to visit, but let me tell you about brunch! The food and drinks tasted so incredibly fresh and delicious. The staff was friendly and attentive. Definitely will be coming back!
